awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transparency and the Rule of Law
awd_abstract_narration:
Scholars and policymakers agree that strong legal institutions are essential for economic development and democratic governance, yet efforts to improve the rule of law in post-communist and developing countries have frequently been stymied. Recent experience offers little hope for successful top-down reforms, as entrenched elites are well-placed to undermine such efforts. This project therefore contributes to the study of law and social science and to the development of effective policies for building the rule of law by shifting attention to an innovative bottom-up, citizen-led effort to improve judicial transparency: the videotaping of court hearings by civil society organizations. The study's focus on Ukraine is particularly timely given that the United States has in recent years devoted extensive resources to support Ukrainian rule-of-law reforms in recognition of Ukraine's prominent role in ongoing geopolitical conflicts between Russia and the West. 

The study will consist of a large-scale field experiment. Random assignment of court sessions to "treatment" (videotaping) and "control" (no videotaping) conditions will facilitate rigorous evaluation of citizen-led transparency initiatives' impact on key elements of the rule of law, including judicial outcomes, judges' and prosecutors' adherence to procedural rules, and lawyers' perceptions of the judiciary's fairness and independence. Analyses will draw on surveys of lawyers and administrative data collected from Ukrainian courts. The research will result in a novel data set covering approximately 2000 court sessions from five Ukrainian cities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project examines state-society relations in Ukraine during war drawing on a multi-wave online panel survey of residents of Ukraine.  Scholars have long debated how war recasts how citizens and states interact. During war citizens urgently require the state’s protection from foreign invaders and their fellow citizens; while the state urgently requires the citizenry’s tax revenue and mobilized manpower (Levi 1988, pp. 105, 208; Tilly 1992). Despite the importance of understanding how wars shape citizen consent to be governed by the state, systematic empirical studies are rare in large part due to the difficulty of gathering data at the individual level during a military conflict.  We take advantage of the war in Ukraine and the country’s well-developed infrastructure for conducting online surveys to study this topic.   

We seek to identify the factors that influence citizens’ willingness to pay taxes to the state, fight on the state’s behalf, and to respect the state’s laws.  The willingness of citizens to comply with the demands of the state are shaping the ability of the Ukrainian state to respond to Russian aggression in the current moment and will also go a long way to determining the capacity of the Ukrainian state in the long run.  We are especially interested in assessing the impact of two factors on citizens’ willingness to comply with the demands of the state.  First, we examine how citizen perceptions of government performance influence their relations with the state. To this end, we gather detailed evidence on how citizens evaluate the state’s performance in policies related and unrelated to the war effort.  

Second, we recognize that citizens’ willingness to make sacrifices also depends on their perceptions of their compatriots’ decisions to contribute to the common good.  For example, whether one pays taxes or serves in the military is likely to be influenced by whether one expects other citizens to pay their taxes or obey conscription.  To this end, we provide aggregate information to respondents about their compatriots’ answers about taxation, conscription, and compliance with laws to examine how this might change the respondent’s views. This may help us learn, for example, whether telling citizens that many of their fellow citizens believe that paying taxes is important increases a respondent’s reported willingness to pay taxes.  

We also examine the impact of other factors, including citizen perceptions of the efforts of the international community in Ukraine.  This should allow us to gauge how foreign aid shapes efforts at societal resilience and state building in contemporary Ukraine - two important issues for US foreign policy. Finally, we explore how exposure to the costs of war shape support for the state and the war effort.  Whether citizens more exposed to conflict are more or less likely to engage in pro-social behaviors by, for example, paying taxes, following the law, and sacrificing for the war effort is an unresolved question among scholars (Shai 2021).  

To date, we have conducted the first wave of our multi-stage survey and collected more than 12,000 responses that we are currently analyzing.  We have also written a concept paper that lays out the main goals of the project and our methodology, as well as our expectations about the impact of results. We aim to repeat the survey with the same respondents at least three more times at intervals of 4-6 months so that we can track changes in state society relations over time. We will provide brief descriptive reports following each wave of the survey, while also producing academic articles and policy briefs informed by our research.  Finally, we hope that the unique data provided by this project will be widely used by the academic community to better understand state society relations after war. We also hope that our results will be useful to policymakers designing responses that will aid in the reconstruction of the Ukrainian state and society.
